hints_html: A question like this is solved best through logarithmic differentiation. However one could do this by using the product rule (see the alternate solution).
hints_latex:
A question like this is solved best through logarithmic differentiation.
However one could do this by using the product rule (see the alternate
solution).
hints_raw: A question like this is solved best through logarithmic differentiation. However one could do this by using the product rule (see the alternate solution).
sols_html:
We can solve this problem by using logarithmic differentiation.

\[\begin{aligned} \ln(f(x)) &= \ln \left((x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4)\right)\\ &= 7 \ln (x^2+1) + 5 \ln (x^4+2) + 3 \ln (x^6+3) + \ln (x^8+4)\end{aligned}\]

Differentiating implicitly yields

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{f(x)} f'(x)&= \frac{7}{x^2+1}\cdot 2x + \frac{5}{x^4+2}\cdot 4x^3 + \frac{3}{x^6+3}\cdot 6x^5 + \frac{1}{x^8+4} \cdot 8x^7\end{aligned}\]

So

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x)&= (x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4) \left(\frac{14x}{x^2+1} + \frac{20x^3}{x^4+2} + \frac{18x^5}{x^6+3} + \frac{8x^7}{x^8+4} \right)\end{aligned}\]

Alternatively, we could solve this problem â€˜normally\(^{\prime}\) by using product and chain rule.

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x)&=7(x^2+1)^6(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4)\cdot2x + 5(x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^4(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4)\cdot4x^3\\ &\quad + 3(x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^2(x^8+4)\cdot 6x^5 + (x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3\cdot 8x^7\end{aligned}\]

Note that we made use of the general product rule:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx}(f_1 f_2 f_3 f_4)&= \frac{df_1}{dx} f_2 f_3 f_4 + f_1 \frac{df_2}{dx} f_3 f_4 + f_1 f_2 \frac{df_3}{dx} f_4 + f_1 f_2 f_3 \frac{df_4}{dx}. \end{aligned}\]

which can be found by applying the product rule 3 separate times.
sols_raw:
We can solve this problem by using logarithmic differentiation.

<math>\begin{align}
\ln(f(x)) &= \ln \left((x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4)\right)\\
&= 7 \ln (x^2+1) + 5 \ln (x^4+2) + 3 \ln (x^6+3) + \ln (x^8+4)
\end{align}</math>

Differentiating implicitly yields

<math>\begin{align}
\frac{1}{f(x)} f'(x)&= \frac{7}{x^2+1}\cdot 2x + \frac{5}{x^4+2}\cdot 4x^3 + \frac{3}{x^6+3}\cdot 6x^5 + \frac{1}{x^8+4} \cdot 8x^7
\end{align}</math>

So

<math>\begin{align}
f'(x)&= (x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4) \left(\frac{14x}{x^2+1} + \frac{20x^3}{x^4+2} + \frac{18x^5}{x^6+3} + \frac{8x^7}{x^8+4} \right)
\end{align}</math>
Alternatively, we could solve this problem ‘normally’ by using product and chain rule.

<math>\begin{align}
f'(x)&=7(x^2+1)^6(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4)\cdot2x + 5(x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^4(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4)\cdot4x^3\\
&\quad + 3(x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^2(x^8+4)\cdot 6x^5 + (x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3\cdot 8x^7\end{align}</math>

Note that we made use of the general product rule:

<math>\begin{align}
\frac{d}{dx}(f_1 f_2 f_3 f_4)&= \frac{df_1}{dx} f_2 f_3 f_4 + f_1 \frac{df_2}{dx} f_3 f_4 + f_1 f_2 \frac{df_3}{dx} f_4 + f_1 f_2 f_3 \frac{df_4}{dx}. \end{align}</math>

which can be found by applying the product rule 3 separate times.
statement_html: Find the derivative of the function \(f(x)=(x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4).\) (There is no need to simplify your answer.)
statement_latex:
Find the derivative of the function
$f(x)=(x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4).$ (There is no need to simplify
your answer.)
statement_raw: Find the derivative of the function <math>f(x)=(x^2+1)^7(x^4+2)^5(x^6+3)^3(x^8+4).</math> (There is no need to simplify your answer.)
